Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: IEEE IPDPS Conference Student Participation Support

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support 25 students to attend the IEEE International Parallel & Distributed Processing Symposium (IPDPS'14) conference in Phoenix. This is a premier international conference in parallel and distributed computing. This will help students develop their technical strength and engage more closely in the parallel and distributed computing community. The workshop will increase the likelihood of these students staying in the research community, and will thus lead to a more talented and more productive research workforce.

The IPDPS 2014 student program will provide a comprehensive venue to better prepare students for research and career paths in parallel and distributed computing. Participating students will have the opportunity to both present their research and interact with senior academic and industry people in an informal setting. In addition, mentoring sessions will be organized to help students improve communication skills, obtain valuable information for career planning, get familiar current research topics, and make valuable contacts, as well as participating in the IPDPS main conference and associated workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF funding supported 52 students participating in the 28th IEEE International Parallel & Distributed Processing Symposium (IPDPS’14) held in Phoenix, Arizona on May 19-23, 2014. The IPDPS Conference provided student travel grants to encourage participation by students where they can explore opportunities for technical growth and broader engagement with the community at large. Travel awards were in the form of reimbursement post conference participation. There were about 23 awards for international student participants as well, those awards were funded from IEEE-TCPP funds. 

PhD Forum was the main vehicle that spearheaded student engagement activities at IPDPS. There were many activities, including (1) Workshop on writing and presentation skills; Poster presentation training, (2) Working in industry; Panel with industry VIPs, meeting and making plans, (3) Working in academia; Panel with academic VIPs, meeting and making plans; (4) Presenting posters for real, and (5) Special lunch course ­­ Energy Efficiency in Computation. These activities facilitated excellent opportunities for workforce development in the parallel & distributed procssing and high performace computing areas.

Feedback from participants was overwhlemingly positive. A number of students reported that they would not have been able to attend IPDPS without the travel funds, some even reported a need to increase the amount of travel funding. Activities focussed on techical growth of students were received very well. 

This project thus helped train 52 young researchers to become more involved and stay connectd with the parallel and disributed computing discipline. These individuals would certainly advance the discilpine. 

 IPDPS organization committee has decided to continue and expand PhD Forum activities for future conferences. In fact, other conferences have borrowed these ideas and initiated a few of the similar stuent engagement activities in their meetings.
